course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Economic Development
course.description: This course examines the economic situations of low and middle-income economies, considering many important topics in the field of development economics. It addresses questions such as what factors help explain why some countries are rich and others poor and whether economic policies can affect these factors. We will study key aspects of life for poor households in the developing world, such as inequality, gender and the intra-household division of resources, education, child labor, health, savings and credit, institutions and globalization. Students will also study recent research in the field and examine empirical evidence on these topics. Prior knowledge in introductory economics and basic statistics is beneficial.

reviews.author: 快樂肥仔
reviews.comment_content:
I. Introduction: What is Economic Development?
II. Determinants of Economic Growth
III. Inequality and Poverty
IV. Population, Fertility and Gender
V. Education (and Child Labor)
VI. Savings, Credit Markets and Microfinance
VI. Leaders and Institutions

The content is very practical even for those who are not interested in economics, some influential and inspiring papers are discussed in this course. A few parts of the content are related to methodology, like how to design a difference-in-difference analysis and how to set up randomized controlled trials. The concepts taught in this course will be very useful for you to understand what is going on in the world.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Sometimes it may be a little bit difficult to understand what the professor says because of her accent, but overall, she is a nice person, she is willing to help and answer our questions.

For the content part, I think it is very difficult to utilize the things we have learned from lectures in the exams, you may have totally understood the concepts explained in the lessons but still do not know how to complete the assignments and exams.

The TA is a disaster, I can only see her existing during the midterm and final exams, but it feels like she has no idea what is happening, she doesn't know the exact starting time of the exam and she doesn't even know the course code.
reviews.comment_grading:
The final grading scheme is as follows.

30% Final Exam
- Mean: 63.8 High: 82 Low: 20

25% Midterm Exam
- Mean: 62.8 High: 82 Low: 33 SD: 13.95

The exams are super challenging and the professor has said that she does not expect we are going to finish all the questions.

15% Reading report

There is no specific requirement on the length or the content of the report, around 3-5 pages with double space is acceptable.

15% Problem Sets (3 throughout the semester)
- Mean: 3.8 High: 4.9 Low: 0
- Mean: 4.1 High: 5 Low: 2.5
- Mean: 4.3 High: 5 Low: 3

Just show your effort and completeness, the accuracy of your answer does not matter.

5% Class Participation (including class attendance and other in-class activities)

My score:
Almost the highest in midterm & slight above mean in final = A-

The grading is not as poor as I thought.

reviews.author: Chapmann
reviews.comment_content: This is an interesting course, the course explains the relation of economics with different social situations, which correlates economic concepts with concepts like poverty, education, etc. It is an interesting course, provided you have some higher standard in mathematics, probably a foundation in economics (like high school). Otherwise, you might not be able to fully understand and enjoy looking at the materials in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher is nice actually, but her English is a very tough task for me. It is quite hard to understand even with the assistance of the PowerPoint. But she is willing to discuss our questions with us.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is fine given that you really make effort to study. The exams are tough, but the assignments (problem sets) and the reading report can help you gain some marks. The problem sets are just merely counting marks on your effort, as she doesn't look for 100% completion but just wanting to see students attempt the questions.
reviews.comment_workload: Usually, it consists of 1 midterm, 1 final, 3 problem sets, and a reading report. But my semester was kinda different due to the social situation in Hong Kong. (I spent the latter part of the semester at home due to suspension of classes). Thus I only had 1 midterm (25%), 2 small problem sets of five questions each(15%), a reading report ( 30%) and a big problem set that had 10 questions( 30%).

reviews.author: secretangel
reviews.title: Sosc3120
reviews.comment_content:
Economic growth
Inequality and Poverty
Population
Education

The content is quite hard for me (I have some economic background). So, it will be even harder for someone who has not studied any economic course before.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher is patient and willing to answer students' questions, but her accent is interesting. Sometimes you have to pay much attention if you want to know what she is talking about,
reviews.comment_grading:
I left many questions blank in the final exam and I got a B+ in the course.

For your reference:
my three Problems set got full marks
Mid-term got 1-2 SD higher than the Mean
reviews.comment_workload:
Not much homework, only three problem sets.
1 Mid-term
1 final

reviews.author: ching_tc
reviews.comment_content:
content will be kinda harsh if you are not too interested in maths
it teaches econ concepts on topics like credit system, population, Solow model, gender, edu etc.
personally, I dont find the courses content interesting but you may find it easy if you have taken some other econ courses in UST i think

the teacher's English is kinda cute
but if you pay enough attention to it, I think you can still understand it

reviews.author: haida
reviews.title: econ 3120
reviews.comment_content: Overall, it was an average course. Very macroecononomics concentrated.  The assignments were very much similar to the examples provided on the textbook.
reviews.comment_teaching: She was a detailed teacher. Prompt to answer questions via email. The test material was more from the ppt slides, then from the textbook.
reviews.comment_grading: Overall the grading was fair. The assignments were not too hard. And the TA was willing to help.
reviews.comment_workload: There were two assignments, midterm, and final. The exam questions were similar to the assignments. the final exam was cumulative, and it was still hard for me even after I devoted some time.

reviews.author: Brian JIANG
reviews.comment_content:
非常宏經的一門課。期中之前就重點講Simple Solow Model，期中之後覆蓋教育、Credit等內容。個人非常喜歡這麼課的原因在於教授在講清楚理論之後都會用幾篇其實是Graduate School才會讀的論文輔佐理解。提到的論文如果去細細閱讀體會，越發喜歡政經之餘，還能學到非常多新奇的觀點和實踐。
總之，這是一門有ambition的課。發展經濟學是關注人類福祉的學科，對於這樣的學問有熱忱的同學不要錯過。
reviews.comment_teaching: 教授英文不是特別好，但是足夠理解。唯一的缺點在於有時候講的太慢，導致學期結束還有很多內容沒有講完。
reviews.comment_workload:
在3開頭的課中並不算多。只有兩次Assignment，以及Midterm和Final。這學期的Midterm和final還是non-cumulative。
因為有很多的論文可以讀，所以是一門你想努力workload就能很大，但是混一混也能過去的課。
